medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Diarrhea, suspected irritable bowel. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Normal colonoscopy. PREMEDICATIONS: Versed 5 mg, Demerol 75 mg IV. REPORTED PROCEDURE: The rectal exam revealed no external lesions. The prostate was normal in size and consistency. The colonoscope was inserted into the cecum with ease. The cecum, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, transverse colon, splenic flexure, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum were normal. The scope was retroflexed in the rectum and no abnormality was seen, so the scope was straightened, withdrawn, and the procedure terminated. ENDOSCOPIC IMPRESSION: Normal colonoscopy - no evidence of inflammatory disease, polyp, or other neoplasm. These findings are certainly consistent with irritable bowel syndrome.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Diarrhea, thought to be irritable bowel syndrome.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Normal colonoscopy.  

PREMEDICATIONS: Versed 5 mg, Demerol 75 mg IV.  

PROCEDURE: A rectal exam found no visible problems outside the anus. The prostate looked normal in size and feel. The colonoscope was easily passed into the cecum. The cecum, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, transverse colon, splenic flexure, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum all appeared normal. The scope was bent back in the rectum and no abnormality was seen, so it was straightened, pulled out, and the procedure was finished.  

ENDOSCOPIC FINDINGS: The colonoscopy was normalâ€”no signs of inflammation, polyps, or cancer. These results match what we would expect for irritable bowel syndrome.
